These spores are ingested by Daphnia during filter-feeding, and they subsequently germinate and release their infectious contents into the host's cells. The parasite then replicates within the host's tissues, ultimately leading to the death of the Daphnia.

Mitosporidium daphniae has been studied extensively as a model organism for understanding the ecological and evolutionary dynamics of host-parasite interactions in aquatic ecosystems. Its impact on Daphnia populations can have significant consequences for the overall structure and function of freshwater food webs.
